reporter_caption.center: THE STATE OF OHIO v. NORMAN, 155 Ohio St. 607 (1951)

caption.center: THE STATE OF OHIO, APPELLEE v. NORMAN, APPELLANT.

syllabus.italic: Supreme Court — Dismissal — No debatable constitutional question
involved — Criminal law — Operation of "numbers game" —
Conviction of "pick-up" man — Section 13064-1, General Code —
Evidence — Items used in "numbers game" found in "writer's
house" — Telephone calls for accused at "writer's house" —
Intercepted by policeman when accused refused to answer calls —

opinion.posture: APPEAL from the Court of Appeals of Hamilton county.
opinion.attorneys:
Mr. C. Watson Hover, prosecuting attorney, and Mr. Kenneth P.Mooter, for appellee.
Mr. Owen K. Blythe and Mr. William F. Hopkins, for appellant.
opinion.opinion_text:
It is ordered and adjudged that this appeal as of right be, and the same hereby is, dismissed for the reason that no debatable constitutional question is involved.
Appeal dismissed.
WEYGANDT, C.J., ZIMMERMAN, STEWART, MIDDLETON, TAFT, MATTHIAS and HART, JJ., concur.
